creator.name: Bark Beetle Mycobiome Research Coordination Network

description: {"blocks":[{"key":"dgju2","text":"This protocol describes the different methods to collect and preserve bark ambrosia beetles. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8iidp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8ugoh","text":"This protocol is part of the Bark Beetle Mycobiome (BBM) Research Coordination Network. For more information on the BBM international network: Hulcr J, Barnes I, De Beer ZW, Duong TA, Gazis R, Johnson AJ, Jusino MA, Kasson MT, Li Y, Lynch S, Mayers C, Musvuugwa T, Roets F, Seltmann KC, Six D, Vanderpool D, \u0026 Villari C. 2020. Bark beetle mycobiome: collaboratively defined research priorities on a widespread insect-fungus symbiosis. Symbiosis 81: 101–113 https://doi.org/10.1007/s13199-020-00686-9.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":457,"length":42}],"data":{}},{"key":"4pi9h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b3de4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1gn9","text":"This new version of the protocol contains this link that takes you to a supplemental video with extra context and tips, as part of the protocols.io Spotlight series, featuring conversations with protocol authors","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":47,"length":4}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"8F159DF71DD711EBBFC30A58A9FEAC2A","url":"https://doi.org/10.1007/s13199-020-00686-9"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"4D9B5050FF0F11ED82E5EFC9B433F791","url":"https://youtu.be/brsDrqdxN_U"}}}}
document: {"blocks":[{"key":"v0kk","text":"The selection of tools partly depends on which types of scolytine beetles you are mostly interested in. For example, for twig bark beetles you will not need any of the heavy duty hardware. On the other hand, trying to pry ambrosia beetles out of a branch with a knife routinely leads to squashed specimens (for xylophages we recommend sawing out a wood “cookie” with the gallery in it, splitting it out with a chisel, and peeling pieces off with clippers, until you get at the beetle). Our recommendations of brands are based on years of experience, not on any relationship with the vendors.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a287a","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"agm29","text":"The rule number one: do not try to take the beetle out of wood/bark, instead, take the wood/bark away of the beetle: slowly, gently, systematically. Also, do not break twigs by hand and do not use a knife.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9v54u","text":"","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5vtsd","text":"Collecting tools","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7ph1p","text":"The selection of tools partly depends on which types of scolytine beetles you are mostly interested in. For example, for twig bark beetles you will not need any of the heavy duty hardware. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f418c","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7f7ls","text":"Many researchers take a knife as a first tool of choice. A knife tends to be a poor bark beetling tool that results in many squashed specimens. Our recommendations of brands are based on years of experience, not on any relationship with the vendors.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6ujik","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"tjf6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c18is","text":"Essential","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a9rnt","text":"box cutter (heavy duty)","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"at625","text":"anvil-style clippers (we use Bahco anvil pruner)","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fjlqj","text":"hatchet (we use Kershaw Camp Axe)","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aa9cq","text":"folding remove beetles with soft forceps.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":24},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":32,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ekvh6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2cgh9","text":" trunk: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":29}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"64vs5","text":"Cut off a “cookie” or a wedge from the chisel","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"11nid","text":"Clip wood with twine","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1q885","text":"Twist-ties or cable ties","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"era9i","text":"Tape (electrical)","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e471h","text":"Lures, or \u003e95% un-denatured etoh","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b0756","text":"Bags for pipette","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1qq4m","text":"Collection bags, various sizes (for carrying sticks to dissect later)","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e7138","text":"For live specimens, vials with wood flour media","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"81hfo","text":"Labeling equipment (Pigma pens, labels)","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8uuuf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fd5at","text":"Lures","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9tndt","text":"For ethanol lure – attach a mini ziploc bag made of thin plastic, fill half way with ethanol, and poke many hole above the ethanol level.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"86lv0","text":"Take ethanol squirt bottle with you to the field and fill them on site. Change every couple of days (otherwise ethanol will soak up water from the environment).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"77mqn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c6ea0","text":"For dead and well preserved beetles: use upside-down bottle with ethanol in the bottom (no need for ethanol lure bag).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":36}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4no20","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":5,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ajhto","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fvnnt","text":"For live beetles: use smaller bottle attached to the bottom of flight-intercept bottle. The connector can be made of many things, for example plumbing insulation foam or electric tape. Cover the bottom of the small bottle with shreds of paper towel. Big chunks of paper are not good – then don’t cover the slippery bottom, and beetles have nothing to grab on. Remove live beetles every couple of days (daily is best), and change towel shreds every two weeks at least.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"53as4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5dhth","text":"Light-trapping","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"38o4c","text":"Light source of choice, batteries, etc.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"93ao9","text":"We typically use at least two white (UltraFire Sk98 Cree Xml-t6) and two black (UltraFire SK98 UV) flashlights per sheet","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5th5f","text":"Voltage converter if necessary","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dmb1","text":"glasses with UV protection","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9k3ar","text":"White sheet (Queen size is branches","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"di33i","text":"A bait branch bundle is an amazing way to collect twig borers. These are some of the most diverse bark and ambrosia beetles. Make sure you use a meaningful host, and do it in the correct season. Ideally you would want to pull it up to the canopy, or at least get it off the ground, but not in direct sunlight. The bigger bundle the better! The one on this picture is pretty small.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2r57t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"degus","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":6,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3pd2u","text":"Storing Beetles","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e5dud","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[{"key":7,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"pm9t","text":"Beetle Identification after collecting.","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":39}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"domqf","text":"Larvae can be collected if DNA identification will be carried out. If it is not needed, well preserved specimens will suffice. A skilled taxonomist can identify species faster and better than molecular tools in most cases.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9s95v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f3v4m","text":"Reporting
